{{eastern name order|Huang Yasheng}} {{chinese name|[[Huang (surname)|Huang]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Yasheng Huang | image = Huang Yasheng.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Huang at The Emerging Markets Summit, 2009 | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Beijing]], China | death_date = | death_place = | residence = USA | nationality = | citizenship = American | other_names = | known_for = expertise on international business, political economy, and international management | education = [[B.A]] (Government)
[[Ph.D]] (Government) | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]
([[John F. Kennedy School of Government]]) | employer = MIT Sloan School of Management, Fudan University, Harvard Business School, University of Michigan | occupation = [[Author]], [[economic strategist]], [[professor]] | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Yasheng Huang''' (Chinese: 黄亚生) is an American [[professor]] in [[management|international management]] at the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]], where he founded and heads the [[China Lab]] and [[India Lab]]. His research areas include [[human capital]] [[capital formation|formation]] in [[China]] and [[India]]. He had previous appointments at the University of Michigan and Harvard Business School. Huang is the author of ''Capitalism with Chinese Characteristics'', a [[Economic history of the People's Republic of China|history]] of [[economic reforms in China]]. ==Early life and education== Dr. Huang was born in [[Beijing]], China. He moved to the United States to pursue his higher education, and enrolled for a [[B.A.]] degree program, with a major in government from Harvard College; which he completed in 1985. Upon completion; he went on to earn a [[Ph.D.]] in government from [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] at Harvard University in 1991. ==Career== While he was preparing for his Ph.D, he worked as a [[World Bank]] consultant and associate professor at the University of Michigan from 1987 to 1989. In 1997, he joined [[Harvard Business School]] as the Associate Professor in business, government and international economics. He is currently a professor in international management at the MIT Sloan School of Management, joined in 2003. At MIT, he founded and heads the China Lab and India Lab. His research areas include [[human capital]] [[capital formation|formation]] in [[China]] and [[India]]. ==Bibliography== Dr. Huang’s scholarly works and articles have been published in a number of economics and management journals, and publications including TheWall Street Journal, The Economist, and Businessworld. He also authored / co authored books on topics – [[globalization]] and [[emerging markets]]; [[Foreign direct investment|FDI]], [[Investment strategy|Investment strategies]], [[Economic liberalization|financial liberalization]] in China. A selection of his books and articles, are the following; * '''Books (author)''' ** {{cite book |last=Huang |first=Yasheng |title=Inflation and Investment Controls in China |year=1996 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] | isbn=9780521554831 |url=http://www.cambridge.org/aus/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521554831 |ref=Huang1996}} ** {{cite book |last=Huang |first=Yasheng |title=Fdi in China: An Asian Perspective |year=1998 |publisher=[[Southeast Asia Institute|Institute of Southeast Asian Studies]] | isbn=9789813055872 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Fdi_in_China.html?id=WfA0GpGOOLQC&redir_esc=y |ref=Huang1998}} ** {{cite book |last=Huang |first=Yasheng |title=Selling China : Foreign Investment during the Reform Era |year=1998 |publisher=Cambridge University press |isbn=9780521814287 |url=http://www.cambridge.org/asia/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521814287 |ref=Huang2003}} ** {{cite book |last1=Saich |first1=Tony |last2=Steinfeld |first2=Edward |last3=Huang |first3=Yasheng |title=Financial Reform in China |year=2005 |publisher=Harvard University Asia Center |isbn= |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Financial_sector_reform_in_China.html?id=crjsAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y |ref=Huang2005}} ** {{cite book |last=Huang |first=Yasheng |title=Capitalism with Chinese Characteristics |year=2008 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9780521898102 |url=http://www.cambridge.org/aus/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521898102 |ref=Huang2008}} * '''Articles''' ** Yasheng Huang, [[Tarun Khanna]] (July 2003); [https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2003/07/01/can_india_overtake_china Can India Overtake China?]; Foreign policy ** Yasheng Huang (July/August 2008); [https://foreignpolicy.com/users/login.php?story_id=4345&URL=https://foreignpolicy.com/story/cms.php?story_id=4345 The Next Asian Miracle]; Foreign Policy magazine; ** Yasheng Huang (December 2008); [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122988679995424611 The China Growth Fantasy]; Wall Street Journal; ** Yasheng Huang (January 2011); [http://www.nbr.org/publications/element.aspx?id=481 Rethinking the Beijing Consensus]; Asia Policy; ==Personal life== {{Empty section|date=March 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |title=Biography, Yasheng Huang, Professor of Global Economics and Management, MIT |url=http://mitsloan.mit.edu/faculty/detail.php?in_spseqno=21373&co_list=F |publisher=mitsloan.mit.edu |accessdate=22 July 2012}} {{cite web |title=TED Bio of Yasheng Huang |url=http://www.ted.com/talks/yasheng_huang.html |publisher=TED Talks |accessdate=22 July 2012}} {{cite web |title=Bio of Yasheng Huang |url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/1244364.htm |publisher= |accessdate=22 July 2012}} {{cite web |title=Bio |url=http://www.cf40.org.cn/html/CF40guandian/xingming63/200807/16-162.html |publisher=T |accessdate=22 July 2012}} {{cite news |title=China's rise relied on a rural miracle. So does its future |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/may/17/china-economy-global-crisis |publisher=Guardian |accessdate=22 July 2012 |location=London |first=Yasheng |last=Huang |date=17 May 2009}} }} == External links == * {{Official website|http://web.mit.edu/yshuang/www/}} * {{TED speaker}} ** [http://www.ted.com/talks/yasheng_huang "Does democracy stifle economic growth?" (TEDGlobal 2011)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Huang, Yasheng}} [[Category:Business educators]] [[Category:Chinese business theorists]] [[Category:Chinese emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Business School faculty]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:MIT Sloan School of Management faculty]] [[Category:University of Michigan faculty]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Distinguish|Guo Zengyuan}} {{Infobox person | name = Zeng Guoyuan | image = Zeng-Guoyuan-Toa-Payoh-HDB-Hub-19-August-2011.png | image_size = 200px | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1953}} | birth_place = Singapore | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Singapore]] | other_names = Chan Hock Seng
Zeng Guoyan
Parrot Man
Zeng Guoyung (erroneous) | education = | occupation = Businessman
Politician
Philanthropist
Author
Former acupuncturist | employer = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = Workers' Party (1991)
Independent (1991{{endash}}present) | spouse = Han Yizi (born 1956) | children = 2 | website = | footnotes = }} {{Chinese-name|[[Zeng]]}} '''Zeng Guoyuan''' ({{zh|s=曾国原|t=曾國原|p=Zēng Guŏyuán}}; {{IPAc-cmn|z|eng|1|-|g|uo|2|-|yuan|2}}; born 1953), also known as '''Zeng Guoyan''', '''Thomas Chan Hock Seng''' and, erroneously, '''Zeng Guoyung''',{{cite news|title=Acupuncturist touched my breast, says woman|page=19|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=4 March 1988|quote=But the acupuncturist, Zeng Guoyung, 36, instead accused her of cooking up the story to seek the attention of her jealous boyfriend.}}{{cite news|title=Acupuncturist tells of couple's 'extortion bid'|first=Nancy|last=Loh|date=5 March 1988|newspaper=The Straits Times|page=12|quote=Zeng Guoyung, 36, told the magistrate's court [...]}}{{cite news|date=12 April 1988|page=16|title=Accused fails in bid to taint key witness|newspaper=The Straits Times|quote=The trail of acupuncturist Zeng Guoyung, accused of molesting a woman patient, was yesterday adjourned until August.}}{{cite news|date=13 April 1988|title=Instruments used 'could have touched woman'|newspaper=The Straits Times|page=12|quote=Zeng Guoyung, 36, is accused of kissing (...)}}{{cite news|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=14 April 1988|title=Trial of acupuncturist adjourned|page=18|quote=Zeng Guoyung tendered a transcript of a tape [...]}} is a former Singaporean businessman, philanthropist, politician, author, and acupuncturist. Zeng entered politics in 1991, when he became a [[Workers' Party of Singapore|Workers' Party]] member; thereafter he renounced his affiliation to the group and has since become a [[perennial]] candidate in Singaporean elections, albeit often dropping out of contention at the last minute. Zeng was also an active acupuncturist who arranged for global meetings and operated an acupuncture centre in Singapore, later changing his focus to selling healthcare products after a string of molestation lawsuits initiated by his patients. Zeng was diagnosed with terminal cancer in 2014; this necessitated the excision of his entire [[Human nose|nose]], which led to significant facial disfigurement, and he became a tissue paper peddler, abandoning his previous jobs. Aspects of Zeng's life, including his court cases and unorthodox behaviour, have generated controversy and criticism. ==Early life== Zeng was born Chan Hock Seng{{efn|He adopted the legal name of Zeng Guoyuan as an adult; ''Zeng'' being the non-[[romanised]] version of his surname, and ''Guoyuan'' signifying his desire to be a useful asset to Singapore ('''国'''家的资'''原''' [sic]).{{cite book|first=Guoyuan|last=Zeng|authorlink=Zeng Guo Yuan|title=Why The World Trade Centre Collapse So So Fast?|page=Introduction|publisher=Prof. Zeng Medical Centre International|edition=2}}}} in 1953, the eldest son of a clerk and a homemaker. Zeng became estranged with his siblings following a dispute regarding their father's will.{{cite web|url=http://ricemedia.co/the-miserable-existence-of-singapore-parrot-man/|publisher=Rice Media|title=The Miserable Existence of Singapore's Parrot Man|date=25 October 2017|last=Yeoh|first=Grace}} A March 1987 ''[[The Straits Times|Straits Times]]'' report writes that Zeng's highest level of education was [[secondary school]], but Zeng claims to have "a Doctor in Science degree, a Doctor in Medicine degree and a PhD in Complementary Medicine".{{cite news|title=So many titles, but...|last=Lim|first=Jill|page=12|date=30 August 1996|newspaper=The New Paper}} Between 1977 and 1978, he was President of Dale Carnegie Alumni Association's Lion Chapter of Singapore, an oratorical society. ==Career== ===Early career=== Zeng was once a safety officer at a [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]] production platform at [[Pulau Bukom]].{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19850306-1.2.22.7 |title=Acupuncture ad spiked by health officials |date=6 March 1985 |page=8 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} He officially became a member of the Singapore-based political party Workers' Party (WP) on 18 August 1991 because "the [[People's Action Party|PAP]] government obviously wants an opposition in Parliament",{{cite news|title=He joined WP 4 days ago|last=Ng|first=Irene|date=22 August 1991|newspaper=The New Paper}} and was fielded as a candidate for the [[Bukit Timah Single Member Constituency]] in the [[Singaporean general election, 1991|1991 Singaporean general election]].{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19911207-1.2.42.3.5 |title=Zeng Guoyuan pays up for his limo |date=7 December 1991 |page=32 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{closed access}} He netted a quarter of the 22,000 votes cast, losing out to the PAP's Wang Kai Yuen.{{cite news|title=Fined $4,000, so can't stand for GE till 1999|newspaper=The New Paper|date=13 April 1996}}{{cite web|publisher=Singapore Elections Department|title=1991 Parliamentary Elections Results|url=http://www.eld.gov.sg/elections_past_parliamentary1991.html|accessdate=3 January 2016}}{{cite book|title=Whither PAP's Dominance?: An Analysis of Singapore's 1991 General Elections|first=Bilver|last=Singh|year=1992|page=54|isbn=9789679784183|publisher=Pelanduk Publications|location=Malaysia}} Zeng decided to leave the party that year because, in his words, "in politics, all the crows are black".{{cite news|url=http://sg.news.yahoo.com/blogs/singaporescene/medical-shop-owner-contest-smc-171358458.html |title=Medical shop owner to contest in SMC? |date=22 April 2011 |last=Boey |first=Ewen |publisher=Yahoo! News }} In a 1996 lawsuit he was involved in, Zeng stated that he contested the 1991 general election only to gain publicity for his acupuncture business.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19960806-1.2.31.13 |title=Court hears why acupuncturist stood for election |date=6 August 1996 |page=22 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{Closed access}} ===Perennial candidacy=== [[File:ZengGuoYuan2015.jpg|thumb|right|Zeng at the [[Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple]] in December 2015.]] After leaving the Workers' Party, Zeng became a [[perennial candidate]] for election in Singapore. He ran for the Mountbatten Single Member Constituency during the [[Singaporean general election, 2006]], but was unsuccessful.{{cite news|newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] |url=http://www.asiaone.com/print/News/Elections/Story/A1Story20110821-295506.html |date=22 August 2011 |last=Othman |first=Zul |title=They say 'Jee Say' }} Believing himself to be ineligible for candidacy, Zeng decided not to take part in the [[Singaporean general election, 2011|2011 Singaporean general election]]. He had been present at a nomination centre, with the relevant documents in hand, but upon being reminded of an offence he committed in 2009 he ripped them into pieces and stormed out of the venue while repeatedly underscoring that "they have fixed me up" and "you (the reporters present) know what it is all about" without any elaboration. A news anchor at scene observed that Zeng's nomination papers had been left blank all along. In May 2012, Zeng announced his intention to contest the [[Singaporean by-election, 2012|2012 Singaporean by-election]], but did not complete the nomination process. Zeng alleged that he was informed that he could not contest because of an offence he had incurred four years ago – scolding two police officers with vulgarities, to which he argued it was his bird that committed the deed. It was later clarified in an official statement by the Singapore Elections Department that Zeng "did not file his nomination papers".{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120517-346401.html |title=Zeng blames pet bird for conviction |date=17 May 2012 |last=Tong |first=Jia Han |newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] }} During the [[Singaporean by-election, 2013|2013 Singaporean by-election]], Zeng decided not to contest as he suspected a conspiracy against him, claiming that he first needed "the President's pardon". He also explained that he wanted to give in to candidates of higher caliber than him, adding that "[[Fools Rush In Where Angels Fear to Tread|fools rush in where angels fear to tread]]".{{cite news|newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] |url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20130116-396031.html |title=Zeng Guoyan's 5 reasons for not contesting |date=16 January 2013 }} In August 2015, he declared that he would be [[Singaporean general election, 2015|contesting]] the [[Potong Pasir Single Member Constituency]], pledging to "fight until the end",{{cite news|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=27 August 2015|first=Min Kok|last=Lee|title=GE2015: Potential candidates show up at Elections Department to collect nomination forms|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/politics/ge2015-potential-candidates-show-up-at-election-department-to-collect-nomination-forms}} but after less than a week he changed his mind, citing his being the only independent running{{cite news|language=Chinese|title="選舉常客"延續慣例‧曾國原第三度退選 [Zeng Guoyuan withdraws]|url=http://news.sinchew.com.my/node/441516|date=2 September 2015|newspaper=Sinchew}} his good ties with [[Chiam See Tong]] and not wanting his participation to cause a [[three-cornered-contest]] as reasons for his withdrawal.{{cite news|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/general-election/potong-pasir-its-sitoh-versus-lina-chiam-again|title=Potong Pasir: It's Sitoh versus Lina Chiam again|date=2 September 2015|first=Yi Han|last=Lim|newspaper=AsiaOne}} Furthermore, he revealed he could not have secured the [[Deposit (politics)#Singapore|election deposit]] alone and was relying on his "fifteen compassionate backers".{{cite news|url=http://www.channel8news.sg/news8/singapore/20150901-sg-nomination/2090216.html|title=【即时报道】2015大选提名日现场情况 [Nomination Day happenings]|language=Chinese|date=1 September 2015}} ===Other ventures=== [[File:Zeng Guoyuan Vegetable Shampoo.JPG|thumb|A bottle of Zeng's vegetable shampoo.|230x230px]] Having studied the subject in Hong Kong and Taiwan, Zeng is a former acupuncturist,{{cite news|url=http://www.spp.nus.edu.sg/ips/docs/media/yr2012/TD_By%20election%20surprise_160512.pdf |title=By-election surprise |date=16 May 2012 |last=Teo |first=Xuanwei |newspaper=TODAY }} and organised acupuncture meet-ups{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19911127-1.2.28.15 |title=Taipei new venue of acupuncture congress |date=27 November 1991 |page=22 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]}} {{Closed access}}{{efn|Often doubling as a "medical consultant".{{cite news|title=Acupressure for better health and beauty|date=27 May 1985|page=16|newspaper=The Straits Times}}}} as the president of the World Acupuncture Voluntary Organisation (WAVO).{{cite news|language=Malay |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=beritaharian19880605-1.2.15.2 |title=Syarat untuk ikuti latihan |date=5 June 1988 |page=3 |newspaper=[[Berita Harian (Singapore)|Berita Harian]] }}{{efn|Supposedly headquartered in Singapore, but regarding which no credible third-party information exists, apart from a brief 1988 report of a WAVO signboard "needling" a Singaporean male and denting a car after accidentally falling.{{cite news|title=Signboard falls and damages parked car|newspaper=The New Paper|date=4 May 1988}}}} After Zeng published controversial and self-admittedly "misleading" advertisements of it in 1991,{{cite news|title=Dr. Zeng's answer|date=17 May 1991|page=2|newspaper=The New Paper}}{{cite news|title=Acupuncturist told to retract ad|date=17 May 1991|page=2|newspaper=The New Paper}} the 28th World Congress of Acupuncture and Complementary Medicine, which was supposed to have taken place in Singapore, changed its host country to the [[Republic of China]].{{cite news|newspaper=The Straits Times|title=Acupuncture meet in Singapore cancelled|page=11|date=26 November 1991}} Zeng, in defence, cited 'miscommunication' with the Medicina Alternativa Institute in Sri Lanka. He also blamed the local press for this happening and promptly left the Singapore Acupuncture Association.{{cite news|newspaper=The New Paper|title=Association's View|date=17 May 1991|page=2}} As a philanthropist, Zeng funded the construction of a [[mosque]] in an unspecified Bangladeshi village. Zeng is the founder of the Prof Zeng's Medical Centre, which used to be an [[Upper Serangoon Road]]-based acupuncture centre.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19871209-1.2.27.27.3 |title=On molest charge |page=24 |date=9 November 1987 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} It moved to [[Toa Payoh]], at which the sole basis of operations became selling healthcare products, including slimming oil{{cite news|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/The+New+Paper/Story/A1Story20090111-113828.html |title=Toa Payoh's 'nutty professor' |last=Ang |first=Benson |date=11 January 2009 |newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] }} and a "hair regrowth shampoo" made of vegetable and chocolate.{{cite web|title=Hair Regrowth by Prof. Zeng Guoyuan|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jit4tWiYk6I|accessdate=3 March 2015}} He also owned a [[MacPherson, Singapore|MacPherson]]-based store. He drew attention when he used photographs of President of Singapore [[S. R. Nathan]] to endorse his healthcare products, in 2007. The act was deemed as "outrageous" by one Singaporean lawyer, who added that it may constitute [[defamation]].{{cite news|newspaper=[[Lianhe Wanbao]] |date=19 July 2007 |pages=22–23|title=Using photographs of politicians for commercial purposes is an offence|language=Chinese}} Prof Zeng's Medical Centre folded after Zeng contracted cancer. In 2002, Zeng self-published a book on the [[September 11 attacks]], titled ''Why The World Trade Centre Collapse So So Fast?'' ([[sic]]).{{cite news|title=Advertisements|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=14 October 2002|page=3}} The work, which contains numerous references to the 1976 monster thriller ''[[King Kong (1976 film)|King Kong]]'', was banned by the government upon its release. Zeng is listed as an honorary international advisor of the Indian Board of Alternative Medicines, and is the only Singaporean panel member.{{cite web|title=Honorary Advisors (International)|publisher=Indian Board of Alternative Medicines}} ===Media and public image=== Zeng's eccentric personality and mannerisms earned him considerable coverage in local media, and is frequently referred to as '''Parrot Man''', a moniker that came about after Zeng blamed his pet parrot for committing a crime he was charged for.{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/parrot-man-zeng-guoyan-shows-up-for-city-harvest-trial|title="Parrot man" Zeng Guoyan shows up for City Harvest trial|date=15 May 2013|first=Tessa|last=Wong|newspaper=The Straits Times|quote=He gained the nickname "Parrot Man" for blaming his pet parrot for getting him arrested and charged in 2008 for using abusive language at two police officers.}} Benson Ang stressed the controversy surrounding Zeng, describing him as "Toa Payoh's nutty professor". Tessa Wong of ''[[The Straits Times]]'' acknowledged that his appearance during elections "does add colour to what is otherwise a serious day".{{cite news|newspaper=AsiaOne |url=http://www.asiaone.com/print/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20130119-396576.html |date=21 January 2013 |last=Wong |first=Tessa |title=Same actors, different script }} Others facetiously dub him as an "election veteran" in Singapore while noting his tendency of not filing his nomination papers and his public antics;{{cite news|url=http://dailynews.sina.com/gb/news/int/sinchewdaily/20150902/19596890281.html|title=Zeng withdraws|language=Chinese|newspaper=Xinzhou Daily|date=2 September 2015}} Ilsa Chan, writing for Toggle SG, billed Zeng as "the candidate who never gives up" but found his backing out of the 2015 general election bizarre.{{cite web|publisher=Toggle SG|first=Ilsa|last=Chan|url=http://tv.toggle.sg/zh/shows/sgvotes2015/features/ge2015-nominations-the-5602178|title=GE2015 Nominations: The good, the bad and the huh?|date=2 September 2015|accessdate=10 January 2016}} Singaporean comedian and blogger Lee Kin Mun, better known as [[mrbrown]], portrayed Zeng in a satirical video on the 2013 Punggol East by-election.{{cite web|url=http://www.mrbrownshow.com/2013/01/16/the-mrbrown-show-punggol-east-by-election-fever/|publisher=mrbrown|first=Kin Mun|last=Lee|date=16 January 2013|accessdate=6 January 2016|title=Punggol East By-election Fever}} Zeng is notable for his unorthodox, Arab-style clothing, often appearing in his "signature" ''[[thawb]]'', accompanied by either a red-and-white ''[[keffiyeh]]''{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wK_Coz8vtKE&feature=youtu.be|title=Punggol East By-Election Nomination Day - (Before speech by nominated candidates)|publisher=The Online Citizen|accessdate=10 January 2016}} or a golden scarf.{{cite news|newspaper=Yahoo!|date=16 May 2012|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/houngang-by-election--nomination-day-live-blog-coverage.html|title=Hougang by-election: Straight fight between WP's Png Eng Huat and PAP's Desmond Choo}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tw78KoIf-xo|title=Hougang By-Election 2012: Zeng Guoyuan Not Contesting|publisher=Today|accessdate=10 January 2016|date=15 May 2012}} An image of Zeng, outfitted in a ''[[baju kurung]]'' and ''[[songkok]]'', during the 2011 Singaporean general election is available from the photograph repository of the [[National Archives of Singapore]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nas.gov.sg/archivesonline/photographs/record-details/e0299e75-55d2-11e5-ac2a-0050568939ad|title=General Election 2011 - Retired acupuncturist Zeng Guoyuan|accessdate=6 January 2015|publisher=National Archives of Singapore|date=27 April 2011}} ==Personal life== [[File:LiliHan.png|thumb|right|Zeng's spouse, Lili Han Yizi.]] Zeng is married to Lili Han Yizi ({{zh|s=韩仪子|p=Hán Yǐzi}}; born 1956),{{cite news|title=医师非礼女病人案法庭下午聆听陈词 (Closing remarks of case of accused doctor)|newspaper=Lianhe Wanbao|date=4 August 1988|page=5|language=Chinese}}{{cite news|title=针灸师非礼女书记罪名成立罚款两千 (Acupuncturist found guilty of molestation charge, fined two thousand)|newspaper=Lianhe Zaobao|language=Chinese|page=5|date=6 August 1988}}{{cite news|title=针灸医师被控非礼女书记案 双方作了最后陈词推事庭订今天下判 (Molestation case: Final statements from both sides made, verdict to be out today)|language=Chinese|date=5 August 1988|page=5|newspaper=Lianhe Zaobao}}{{Efn|She is erroneously referred to as "Han Yiyu" in a May 1989 ''[[Lianhe Zaobao]]'' report.}} and they have two sons King Yee and King Yew.{{cite news|newspaper=The Straits Times|title=Dad dives to save family trapped in sinking boat|date=8 May 1989|page=28|first=Chan Teik|last=Leong}}{{cite web|url=http://ge.pap.org.sg/viewwu.php?rptid=205 |title=Independent candidate wants to vote for PAP |last=Davie |first=Sandra |publisher=People's Action Party Constituency Portal – Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC |accessdate=29 June 2013 }}{{efn|Both go by the '[[Chan (surname)|Chan]]' surname.{{cite news|title=Son says he peeped as dad treated|date=5 September 1996|page=7|newspaper=The New Paper}}}} A 26 March 1987 ''[[The Straits Times]]'' report on Zeng stated that his English name was Thomas. In a 1996 lawsuit he was involved in, Zeng claimed to have a net worth of ten million dollars. He reportedly took "more than 10 minutes" to recite a list of his qualifications, which included "Senior Professor of the Colombo South Government Hospital" (a claim debunked by the hospital itself) and "Professor at the Medicinal Alternative Open University in the USSR and in Sri Lanka".{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19960830-1.2.53.10 |title=Court hears of his 'assets of $10m and five properties' |page=46 |date=14 August 1996 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{Closed access}} In a series of promotional advertisements the same year, Zeng proclaimed himself to be a "Senior Professor Doctor Sir".{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=biztimes19960229-1.2.15.3 |title=Advertisements |page=6 |date=29 February 1996 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{Closed access}}{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes20021014-1.2.25.1 |title=Advertisements |date=14 October 2002 |page=3 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{Closed access}} Zeng has attracted criticism for his unconventional behaviour. Certain acts of his in public have "annoyed" some individuals; this includes the playing of high-volume videos and Zeng's loud singing. Others opine that his acts provide some form of entertainment. Zeng reportedly is an avid boxer and a former [[taekwando]] instructor. He is also interested in water sports; he owns a speed boat, in addition to ''Scat'', a [[hovercraft]] made in America.{{cite news|last=Seetoh |first=K.F. |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19890311-1.2.27.3.3 |title=Acupuncturist's new love |date=11 March 1989 |page=14 }} In December 1991, Zeng was involved in an accident while on his leisure craft ''Yeeyew'', which he had purchased for $80,000 as a [[Wedding anniversary|tin jubilee]] gift for his wife.{{cite news|title=针灸师潜水救妻儿 (Acupuncturist braves waters to save wife)|language=Chinese|page=1|date=8 May 1989|newspaper=Lianhe Wanbao}} Items on the boat valued at tens of thousands of [[Singapore dollar|dollars]] were lost to the sea. Zeng was hospitalised for a short period following the incident.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19890509-1.2.22.6.2 |title=Stricken boat salvaged, but family's valuables missing |date=9 May 1989 |page=13 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} In February 2013, Zeng sustained a rib fracture and internal bleeding after a traffic collision. Zeng sued the owner of the van involved, OJJ Foods, and the matter was settled out of court in December 2014.''Zeng Guoyuan @ Chan Hock Seng v. Ong Joo Joo Food Industries Pte Ltd'' [2014] [[State Courts of Singapore|State Courts]] (Singapore) In 2014, Zeng underwent surgery to remove his nose, due to terminal [[nasopharynx cancer]];{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/cancer-stricken-parrot-man-now-sells-tissue-paper|newspaper=The Straits Times|title=Cancer-stricken 'Parrot Man' now sells tissue paper|date=29 June 2015|first=Ronald|last=Loh}}{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/messages-gifts-of-support/1730550.html |title=Messages, gifts of support continue to pour in for Mr Lee Kuan Yew |date=21 March 2015 |newspaper=[[Channel NewsAsia]] }} in spite of that, the cancer [[metastasised]], and Zeng had a portion of his large intestine removed shortly afterwards. His [[thyroid]] and [[salivary]] glands were also removed for unspecified reasons. Heavy in debt, he mortgaged his house in May 2015. He peddled [[tissue paper]] outside [[Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple|a Chinese temple]] at [[Queen Street, Singapore|Queen Street]]{{cite news|newspaper=Lianhe Wanbao|title=Election regular Zeng Guoyuan sells tissue paper in a wheelchair|url=http://www.wanbao.com.sg/local/story20150624-57838|language=Chinese|date=26 June 2015}} until late 2016. Travelling about on a [[three-wheeler]] he bought in 1995,{{cite news|url=http://www.guangming.com.my/node/257330?tid=3|title=患3癌剩半年命無家歸‧選舉常客廟前賣紙巾 (Stricken with three cancers; selling tissue paper)|language=Chinese|newspaper=Guangming|date=25 June 2015}} Zeng began frequenting [[Geylang Serai]] and [[Ngee Ann City]] in 2017. He resided with his wife at a "jumbo flat" (comprising two units) in [[Geylang Bahru]]{{cite news|first=Peiting|last=Wong|date=13 August 2017|title='Parrot Man' in tussle with Ngee Ann City management|url=http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/parrot-man-tussle-ngee-ann-city-management|newspaper=Today}} until it was destroyed by a fire in September 2017.{{cite news|first=Chee Kiang|last=Tan|url=http://stomp.straitstimes.com/singapore-seen/fire-at-geylang-bahru-flat-owner-revealed-to-be-parrot-man-who-claimed-to-be-homeless|title=Fire at Geylang Bahru flat: Owner revealed to be 'Parrot Man' who claimed to be homeless|date=13 September 2017|publisher=Stomp}} While on the 1991 campaign trail, Zeng stated his religion as [[Roman Catholicism]].{{cite news|title=WP candidate who admires Lee Kuan Yew|date=30 August 1991|page=28|newspaper=The Straits Times}} In April 2011, Zeng announced that he was a [[Muslim]] and had adopted an Islamic name, Muhammad Ali.{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20110428-276030.html |title=Candidates clarify their focus |date=28 April 2011 |newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] }}{{cite web|title=Independent candidate tears up papers|publisher=RazorTV|accessdate=8 January 2016|date=25 July 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1hK_ecNK_s}} Whilst the trial of [[Kong Hee]] was underway, Zeng endorsed him as a "good preacher" capable of "bring(ing) people to the Lord", adding that he was a Christian who had donated large amounts of money to [[City Harvest Church|City Harvest]] and attended many church sessions. In addition, Zeng claimed to still be partly [[Buddhist]] and that he visited Buddhist temples on a regular basis. When asked for clarification on his religion, Zeng said: {{quote|You can say I'm a member (of City Harvest Church), you can say (unintelligible), but I am everything. I go to the [[mosque]] – I go Monday – (and) I go to the [[Buddhist temple|temple]]; I'm still a Buddhist, if you'd say. Yes, I have a temple in [[Geylang Road|Lorong 15]].{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J3mDPL2_aaY |format=video|title="Parrot man" Zeng Guoyan leaving the Subordinate Courts |date=14 May 2013 }}}} In a 2017 interview, Zeng identified himself as both a Muslim and a [[Jehovah's Witnesses|Jehovah's Witness]], and described the unfortunate happenings in his life as divine salvation. ==Legal affairs== In 1981, Zeng was fined $400 for an advertisement of his which was against the law. In March 1987, Zeng was found guilty of publishing a newspaper advertisement which advertised his piles and pain treatment services – a breach of the Singapore Medical Act. He was fined $1,500.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19870318.2.21.23 |title=Man fined for piles ad |date=26 March 1987 |page=26 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} In March 1988, a clerk filed a lawsuit against Zeng, attesting that he had "kissed her and touched her breast in his clinic" during a hair-loss and weight-gain treatment session in November 1986. Zeng countered that the accuser was merely making use of him to get her "jealous" boyfriend's attention, labelling the case as an "extortion bid". He was found guilty and fined $2,000,{{cite news|title=法庭相信女病人证词 针灸师曾国原非礼罪成罚二千 (Court believes female patient, fines Zeng $2,000)|language=Chinese|date=5 August 1988|page=30|newspaper=Lianhe Wanbao}} but the conviction was rescinded in March 1990, following an appeal by Zeng.{{cite news|date=27 March 1990|title=Acupuncturist wins appeal in molest case|page=22|newspaper=The Straits Times}} In December 1991, the owner of a white [[Mercedes-Benz]] limousine lodged a complaint against Zeng for not having paid for his vehicle, which he rented in November of that year, during the General Election.{{cite news|title=Limousine squabble|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=23 November 1991}} Initially refusing to pay, he later complied and no charges were filed.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19911207-1.2.42.3.5 |title=Zeng Guoyuan pays up for his limo |date=7 December 1991 |page=32 }} {{Closed access}} In June 1994, Zeng was charged with assaulting and threatening two male individuals,{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19940624-1.2.36.21.2 |title=Charged with hurting 2 men |date=24 June 1994 |page=31 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{closed access}} a claim which he initially refuted.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19941028-1.2.37.19 |title=Workers' Party man denies punching two men |date=28 October 1994 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |page=33 }} {{Closed access}} The victims were his neighbours, and one of them was businessman Ho Peng Keong.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19940930-1.2.35.14 |title=PC tells court: I saw businessman walk up to acupuncturist's gate |date=30 September 1994 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |page=30 }} {{Closed access}} Zeng was ordered to pay a fine of [[Singapore dollar|S$]]4,000.{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19941115-1.2.32.11 |title=Workers' Party man fined for hurting neighbours |date=15 November 1994 |page=24 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} {{Closed access}} In April 1996, another female patient of his claimed that Zeng had outraged her modesty at a treatment session at his acupuncture centre. During the trial, Zeng refused to settle in court, repeatedly stating that he was a "knight of Saint John"; the claim was found to be untrue.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19960904-1.2.29.10 |title=Accused cries in court, saying again that he was set up |date=4 September 1996 |page=19 }}{{efn|More specifically, he alleged he had been awarded the "Order of Sovereign Military" by the "Order of Saint John of Jerusalem" in a self-promotional advert.{{cite news|title=Advertisements|page=5|date=6 January 2003|newspaper=The Straits Times}}}} His antics were likened by a police officer at scene to that of a "Shakespearean" actor.{{cite news|title=Shakespearean Drama|date=4 September 1996|page=11|newspaper=The New Paper}} Maintaining his innocence to the end,{{cite news|title=After: Smacks and Shouts|page=6|date=14 September 1996|newspaper=The New Paper}} Zeng was nonetheless found guilty and sentenced to four strokes of the cane and some eighteen months of jail time.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19960914-1.2.5&sessionid=42abe84942dc4b73a55ab7badfe40060 |date=14 September 1996 |page=1 |title=Acupuncturist guilty, gets jail and four strokes }} {{Closed access}} During that period in jail, Zeng alleged that he was stripped of some of his basic rights; he claimed that as a result of being denied access to clean bathing water, he had developed painful rashes near his [[rectum]].{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19960829-1.2.42.13&sessionid=c8e195e568e14f5491f0c2634b5ad0d4 |title=I was mistreated in police lock-up, says acupunturist |date=29 August 1996 |page=33 |newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] }} He added that the police in charge of him called him crazy and wanted to "put him in a psychiatric cell", and also accused them of forcing him to confess through physical means.{{cite news|newspaper=The New Paper|title=I didn't step on Zeng's toe: Officer|date=6 August 1996|page=13}} In 1997, yet another similar accusation was filed against him, and he received ten strokes of the cane and twenty-seven months of imprisonment, after being deemed guilty and a failed appeal.{{cite news|title=Zeng gets higher penalty|date=16 July 1997|newspaper=The New Paper|page=12}}{{cite web|publisher=Singapore Law |url=http://www.singaporelaw.sg/sglaw/laws-of-singapore/case-law/free-law/high-court-judgments/14284-public-prosecutor-v-chow-yee-sze-2010-sghc-259 |title=Public Prosecutor v Chow Yee Sze [2010] SGHC 259 |accessdate=28 June 2013 |quote=Zeng Guoyuan v PP [1997] 3 SLR 321: 9 months for each of the three charges of massaging the breasts and groin of the victim in the course of an acupressure and acupuncture session; [3 strokes for each charge involving touching of breasts and groin]}} Zeng had claimed in defence that the "nasty" victim was spitefully making up lies after he rejected her.{{cite news|newspaper=The New Paper|title=Zeng's version of molest story|date=16 July 1997|page=12}} Efforts on his part to postpone the sentencing, on the grounds that he was mentally disabled, were unsuccessful.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]] |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19970719-1.2.59.2.5 |date=19 July 1997 |title=So you think you are the CJ... |page=46 }} {{Closed access}} It was noted that Zeng's antics in court were "aggravating factor[s] that the Court could take into account in sentencing".{{cite web|url=http://docs.lawsociety.org.sg/criminallaw/index.php/unreported-cases/20-unreported-cases/54-gd-for-ma-2662012-court-8s-case |publisher=Criminal Law Portal |title=Public Prosecutor v Max Wu Guo Hao [2012] SGDC 471 |accessdate=28 June 2013 }} In 2008, Zeng was charged with using abusive language on two police officers. He was found guilty of violating section 13(D) of the Miscellaneous Offences (Public Order and Nuisance) Act and fined $2,500; it was reinforced in ''Public Prosecutor v Zeng Guoyuan'' [2008] that "the tariff for using abusive/threatening language or behaviour is a fine of $3,000".{{cite web|url=http://www.supremecourt.gov.sg/docs/default-source/default-document-library/sjc/gyh_tl_4.pdf|publisher=[[Supreme Court of Singapore|Supreme Court]]|title=The Protection From Harassment Act 2014|accessdate=3 January 2015}} In around October 2009, a lawsuit was filed against Zeng for placing at his two stores banners of then-wanted fugitive [[Mas Selamat bin Kastari]] — which he argued were merely sunshades – without official permit.{{cite news|newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] |url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/the%2BStraits%2BTimes/Story/A1Story20091013-173282.html |title=Mas Selamat banners were sunshades, says accused |last=Singh |first=Khushwant |date=13 October 2009 }} The banners were accompanied by large one-word notes all reading "Death".{{cite news|url=http://www.zaobao.com.sg/special/report/singapore/ge/story20110423-135391|language=Chinese|newspaper=Lianhe Zaobao |title=表示有意到蒙巴登参选 曾国原：是否符合资格待当局查证 (Potential candidate Zeng doubts his own eligibility)|date=23 April 2011}} The trial concluded with Zeng deciding to spend three weeks in jail, instead of paying $3,000 in fines.{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/the%2BStraits%2BTimes/Story/A1Story20091208-184546.html |date=8 December 2009 |title=Man fined $3,000 for Mas Selamat banners |newspaper=[[AsiaOne]] }} The management of Ngee Ann City "called the police more than 30 times" in early 2017, alleging that Zeng was "masquerading as a cripple to sell tissue-paper packs"; Zeng countered that they were simply "not happy" and "jealous" and dismissed their allegations as "nonsense". Additionally, a notice urging passers-by not to donate to Zeng was put up by the mall. Zeng was charged with begging, using abusive language on a police officer, and assaulting a Ngee Ann City security officer. Around End July 2018, Zeng returned to Orchard Road to peddle tissue at the crossing infront of Mandarin Hotel, a video of him was uploaded online and went viral. The video cited that he was causing nuisance and faking as a handicap, and also warned passersby not to believe his rouse. In August 2018, Zeng was arrested for disorderly behaviour in Orchard Road.{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/parrot-man-zeng-guoyuan-arrested-for-disorderly-behaviour-in-orchard-road?|newspaper=The Straits Times|title=Parrot Man Zeng Guoyuan arrested for disorderly behaviour in Orchard Road|last=Goh|first=Timothy|date=26 August 2018}} Two months later, he was arrested in [[Geylang Serai]] for assaulting two police officers.{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/parrot-man-arrested-in-geylang-serai-after-hurting-two-police-officers|title='Parrot Man' arrested in Geylang Serai after hurting two police officers|last=Goh|first=Timothy|date=15 October 2018|newspaper=The Straits Times}} In October 2018, former senior staff sergeant Seah Chin Peng was charged in a district court for deliberately damaging Zeng's walking stick two years ago and attempting to suppress the truth behind its destruction.{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/police-officer-charged-for-damaging-parrot-mans-walking-stick-and-then-lying|newspaper=The Straits Times|title=Police officer accused of damaging 'Parrot Man's' walking stick and then lying about it|last=Alkhatib|first=Sharib|date=19 October 2018}} ==Bibliography== * ''Why The World Trade Centre Collapse So So Fast?'' (2002) (self-published; {{no ISBN}}) ==See also== {{Portal|Singapore|Biography}} * [[Pre-election-day events of the Singaporean general election, 2011]] * [[Ooi Boon Ewe]], another Singaporean perennial candidate ==References== ===Notes=== {{notelist}} ===Citations=== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Commons category}} {{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zeng, Guoyuan}} [[Category:Singaporean people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Singapore]] [[Category:Singaporean businesspeople]] [[Category:Singaporean politicians]] [[Category:Singaporean writers]] [[Category:Workers' Party (Singapore) politicians]] [[Category:Independent politicians in Singapore]]
